expl: Bresenham's Algorithm provides efficient rasterization of lines.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Histogram clipping is not a type of clipping used in graphics.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following is a solid modeling technique?

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Wireframe modeling represents a 3D object using only:
expl: Wireframe modeling represents only edges and vertices of a 3D object.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which modeling technique defines both the shape and volume of an object?
expl: Boundary representation (B-Rep) defines both the shape and the enclosed volume of an object.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Flood Fill algorithm is generally used for:

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following techniques does not represent the volume of an object?

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following is an advantage of B-Rep over wireframe modeling?

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

options: Define 3D object geometry with interior and exterior details

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: In raster graphics, the screen is divided into:
expl: In raster graphics, the screen is divided into a grid of pixels.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: A pixel is:
options: The smallest unit of a raster image
expl: A pixel is the smallest addressable unit in a raster image.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Each pixel in a raster display is generally made up of:
expl: A pixel is usually composed of three sub-pixels: Red, Green, and Blue.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: A dead pixel refers to:
options: A pixel that is always white
A pixel that does not display color at all
A pixel that changes colors rapidly
A pixel used only in vector graphics
expl: A dead pixel is one that fails to light up, appearing black or stuck.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following uses pixels as the basic element of image representation?
expl: Raster graphics rely on pixels to represent images, unlike vector graphics.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: In raster graphics, image quality depends mainly on:
expl: Higher resolution means more pixels per area, giving better image quality.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following is true about raster graphics?
expl: Raster graphics divide the screen into a pixel grid, making them suitable for photos.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: A collection of pixels forms:
expl: Pixels together form a raster image on the screen.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: The intensity and color of a pixel are determined by:
expl: Each pixel’s color is defined by its red, green, and blue sub-pixel values.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which graphics system divides the screen into geometric primitives like lines and curves instead of pixels?
expl: Vector graphics use mathematical primitives like lines, curves, and polygons rather than pixels.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which transformation is NOT affine?
expl: Affine transformations include translation, rotation, scaling, shearing, and reflection. Perspective projection is not affine.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following transformations are included in affine transformations?
expl: Affine transformations include translation, rotation, scaling, reflection, and shearing.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Affine transformations preserve:
options: Ratios of distances along a line
expl: Affine transformations preserve straight lines, parallelism, and ratios along lines.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which transformation can change the shape of an object (e.g., rectangle into a parallelogram)?
expl: Shearing transformation skews an object, converting shapes like rectangles into parallelograms.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Reflection transformation is considered an:

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following is a non-linear transformation?
expl: Perspective projection is non-linear because it does not preserve parallelism.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Affine transformations are represented using:
expl: Affine transformations are expressed using homogeneous coordinate matrices for easy combination.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Scaling increases or decreases object size uniformly without altering its shape.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which affine transformation repositions an object without altering its size, shape, or orientation?
expl: Translation simply moves an object to a new position.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Rotation matrices use trigonometric sine and cosine values for transformation.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which is the typical refresh rate in a raster scan display?
expl: Typical CRT-based raster scan displays refresh at around 60–80 Hz for smooth visual performance.

expl: At refresh rates below 30 Hz, the human eye perceives flicker, making the display uncomfortable.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Refresh rate is measured in frames per second, also called Hertz (Hz).

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which display technology commonly works at 60–80 Hz refresh rate?
expl: CRT monitors typically operate at 60–80 Hz refresh rates to minimize flicker.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Higher refresh rates in raster scan displays result in:
expl: Higher refresh rates reduce flicker and produce smoother, more stable images.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Bezier curves are widely used to represent smooth curves in computer graphics and design.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Bezier curves are mainly used in:
expl: Bezier curves are essential in designing fonts, logos, and CAD applications for smooth curve modeling.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Control points determine the exact shape and curvature of a Bezier curve.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Bresenham’s algorithm is efficient for line drawing using only integer calculations.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Flood fill is a region filling algorithm used in raster graphics to color bounded areas.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: In Bezier curves, what type of curves are generally generated?
expl: Bezier curves are mathematically designed to produce smooth and scalable curves.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Where are Bezier curves commonly used?
expl: Bezier curves are widely used in computer graphics, vector design, and animation.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Bezier curves are parametric curves defined by control points and parametric equations.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

options: Using Mathematical Formulas Based on Control Points
expl: Bezier curves are computed with polynomial formulas based on the given control points.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which color model is based on Red, Green, and Blue components?
expl: The RGB model is an additive color model based on the primary colors of light: Red, Green, and Blue.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which color model is primarily used in color printers?
expl: Printers use the CMYK subtractive model because it is based on ink colors: Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, and Black.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: In the CMYK model, what does ‘K’ stand for?
expl: The ‘K’ in CMYK stands for Key (Black), representing the black component used in printing.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which color model is best suited for human color perception and is used in image processing?
expl: HSV/HSI models are designed to align more closely with human visual perception, making them useful in image editing.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following is a subtractive color model?
expl: CMYK is subtractive because it subtracts light using inks to create colors.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: In the HSV model, ‘V’ stands for:
expl: In HSV, H = Hue, S = Saturation, and V = Value (brightness level).

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which model separates color into Hue, Saturation, and Brightness/Value?
expl: The HSV model represents color in terms of Hue, Saturation, and Value (brightness).

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which color model is used when working with televisions, projectors, and computer screens?
expl: RGB is used in display devices like monitors, projectors, and TVs because they emit light.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Why is the RGB model called an 'additive' color model?
options: It subtracts light to create colors
It combines light to produce other colors
expl: RGB is additive because it adds light of different colors to produce other colors, including white.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: What is the main advantage of using HSI or HSV over RGB in image editing?
options: They align better with human color perception
expl: HSV/HSI align more closely with how humans perceive and adjust color, making them ideal for editing.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which color model is used in monitors and televisions?
expl: Monitors and televisions use RGB as they work with emitted light.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: What does RGB stand for?
expl: RGB stands for Red, Green, and Blue, the primary colors of light.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: RGB is which type of color model?
expl: The RGB model is additive because colors are formed by adding light.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which device does NOT typically use the RGB color model?
expl: Printers use CMYK inks instead of RGB light for color formation.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: In the RGB model, what color is produced when all three colors (R, G, B) are combined at full intensity?
expl: When Red, Green, and Blue lights are combined at full intensity, they produce White.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which color model is primarily used in printing?
expl: Printing is done using CMYK because it is based on subtractive ink colors.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: RGB model is mainly used in which of the following applications?
expl: RGB is used in electronic display devices like mobiles, TVs, and projectors.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the RGB model?
expl: RGB has Red, Green, and Blue components. Yellow is formed by combining Red and Green.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Devices like monitors, TVs, and projectors use the additive RGB color model since they emit light.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: What is the result of combining red and green in the RGB model?
expl: In RGB, combining Red and Green produces Yellow.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: What is scan conversion in computer graphics?
expl: Scan conversion is the process of converting geometric data (lines, shapes) into raster images (pixels) for display.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Rendering requires scan conversion to transform vector data into pixel data for raster displays.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which device typically uses scan conversion to display images?
expl: Monitors rely on scan conversion to render vector data into pixels on the screen.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Scan conversion transforms geometric shapes into pixel-based raster images.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: The primary goal of scan conversion is to:
expl: Its main goal is rendering vector data into a raster format for display.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Which graphics system heavily depends on scan conversion?
expl: Raster graphics systems depend on scan conversion to map geometry to pixels.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Text-to-speech synthesis is unrelated to scan conversion.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Scan conversion converts geometric data like lines, circles, polygons into raster pixels.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Bresenham’s Line Algorithm is widely used for efficient line drawing in scan conversion.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Anti-aliasing smooths jagged edges in digital images.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Supersampling is a common anti-aliasing method.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

options: Converges parallel lines at vanishing point

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

options: Allows depth but keeps front face undistorted
expl: Oblique projection keeps the front face true and adds depth via angled projection.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Flood fill is useful when boundaries are not clearly defined.

options: Edges of objects in raster graphics

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: The display controller transfers the stored image data from memory to the monitor.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: The monitor shows the final output to the user.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Transformation refers to modifying position, size, angle, or shape of objects.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Translation moves an object from one location to another.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: Rotation changes the angle of an object around a pivot point.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Scaling changes:
expl: Scaling modifies the size of an object.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC
text: Shearing causes:
expl: Shearing skews the shape of an object without altering its size.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC

expl: 3D graphics consist of X, Y, and Z axes representing length, breadth, and height.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following is the most commonly used boundary representation for a 3-dimensional graphics object?
expl: Surface polygon is the common boundary representation for 3D objects.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following is the process of digitizing a picture into a set of pixel-intensity for storage in the frame buffer?
expl: Scan conversion digitizes a picture into pixel intensities for frame buffer storage.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following is commonly known as frame buffer on a black and white system with one bit per pixel?
expl: Bitmap stores pixel data as 1 bit per pixel in black-and-white systems.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following algorithm is a faster method for calculating pixel positions?
expl: DDA algorithm is a fast method for calculating pixel positions.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: If the boundary is specified in a single color and the algorithm proceeds pixel by pixel until the boundary color is encountered, it is known as ____
expl: Boundary-fill algorithm proceeds outward pixel by pixel until it meets the boundary color.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following defines a pixel mask?
expl: Pixel masks contain digits 1 and 0 to specify inter-span spacing.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: What does an aspect ratio mean?
options: Ratio of vertical points to horizontal points
Ratio of vertical points to horizontal points and horizontal points to vertical points
Ratio of horizontal points to vertical points
expl: Aspect ratio is the ratio of vertical points to horizontal points and vice versa.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following is a correct abbreviation of DDA algorithm?
expl: DDA stands for Digital Differential Analyzer.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: The Cohen-Sutherland algorithm divides the region into how many spaces?
expl: It divides a 2D space into 9 regions for line clipping.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: The Cohen-Sutherland algorithm is more efficient than the Liang-Barsky algorithm.
expl: Liang–Barsky algorithm is more efficient as it performs fewer calculations.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following is used for 3D positioning, modeling, and animation?
expl: Space ball is a 3D positioning device used for modeling and animation.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following can be used to determine the position on the data tablet?
options: Either Signal strength or coded pulse
expl: Either signal strength or coded pulse determines position on a data tablet.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which type of perspective projection is also called 'Angular Perspective'?
expl: Two-point perspective is also called angular perspective.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which perspective projection is used in drawings of railway lines?
expl: One-point perspective is commonly used for railway and highway drawings.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which representation represents a three-dimensional object?
expl: Equation representation can describe a 3D object mathematically.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which part of a picture is considered and saved in exterior clipping?
options: We don’t consider the picture in exterior clipping
Picture on the edges of the view window
expl: Exterior clipping keeps only the part outside the view window.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which clipping process handles the clipping of strings?
expl: Text clipping determines which parts of strings are kept based on position.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which algorithm can be used to clip a polygon in 3D space?
options: Polygon in 3D space cannot be clipped
expl: Weiler Atherton can clip polygons in 3D using Z-ordering.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: How is the line path on the polygon area for a 45% line?
expl: A 45% line path is centered on the polygon area.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which is defined as sampling object characteristics at high resolution and displaying at lower resolution?
expl: Super-sampling, or post-filtering, averages high-resolution samples to reduce aliasing.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: What is the correct full form of NLN line clipping algorithm?
expl: NLN stands for Nicholl-Lee-Nicholl algorithm, a fast clipping method.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: ‘Skala’ is an example of which type of clipping?
expl: Skala is a line clipping algorithm for rectangular and convex polygon windows.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which of the following is not a type of area sampling?
expl: Point sampling is not considered area sampling; others are weighted/unweighted area methods.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: In which method is a fixed pattern of a line used to generate characters?
expl: Starbust method uses fixed 24-line segments to generate characters.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which stores picture information as a charge distribution behind a phosphor-coated screen?
expl: DVST stores images behind the screen rather than updating them.

title: COMPUTER GRAPHIC 1.0
text: Which device is designed to minimize background sound?
expl: Microphones can be designed to minimize background noise.
